name: physalis-philadelphica
wildlife-value: Bees and other pollinators fertilize the flowers.
edibility: Mature fruits are edible and can be eaten whole with no need to peel core or seed.   They can be used for salsa, soups, stews, and meat dishes.
light: Full sun (6 or more hours of direct sunlight a day)
fruit-description: Round, 1 to 2 inch green or purple berries enclosed in a papery husk have a citrus flavor.  They are ripe when they are still firm but fill the husk.  Green varieties will turn a yellow green when ripe and purple varieties will turn from green to purple.  The papery lantern shaped husks are tan when mature and quite showy.
flower-description: Solitary,  yellow star or bell shaped fused petaled flowers are green or dark in the center.  Their petals can extend backward as they mature and they hang downward in the axils of leaves.
leaf-description: Simple alternate leaves with a toothed margin.  Resemble eggplant leaves.
poison-symptoms: All parts are toxic except the ripe fruits. Headache, stomach pain, lowered temperature, dilated pupils, vomiting, diarrhea, circulatory and respiratory depression, loss of sensation; may be fatal.
